ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the implementation of ethical frameworks in the real world and the challenges that arise from it.
I gained a deeper appreciation for the complexities of data science ethics, especially from a normative standpoint.
This course taught me about the ethical challenges related to data science, as well as modern solutions to ensure fairness in machine learning, AI, and algorithms in general.

I learned a framework for talking about data ethics in various contexts: data collection, algorithmic unfairness/bias, etc. Overall, a remarkably good course if you're looking to gain basic understanding (or contextualize more theoretical classes).

About data ethics, different sorts of consequential Machine learning systems, and also just ethics at large. It was cool to learn about how technology systems are organized and the debates that exist within them.
Strong knowledge in topics in data science ethics

I learned a lot about ethical questions related to data collection, implementation of ML algorithms, and impact of ML model-based decisions. This class opens your eyes to things that you just never thought to consider before.
I learned how and to which extent ethics is currently discussed in the field of data science.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked that the class was a small seminar and we had discussions during every class. It would have been better if we had more readings so we could engage with the material outside of just lectures.

The class covers a number of interesting topics. However, I would have liked to have readings before every class. Without them, the only form of learning came from lectures, so I wasn't as engaged with the material as I had hoped going in.

Weaknesses: it wouldve been cool to be in person! 

Strengths: lovely people, so much interesting conversation among people who I think were passionate about the topic, a lot of opportunities for different types of learning and sharing out what we learned, also just SUPER important material
Not that much structure but very chill class
The course could have been more well-structured.
There was very little week-to-week work for the class. While it was nice to focus on the projects for the class, a few more readings may have made the class more engaging throughout the semester.

One of the seminar's strengths was that it fostered discussions between the students. The discussions were great because the students came from different backgrounds and brought different opinions to the table.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: While I appreciate Prof. Celis's desire to recreate the in-person experience, the breakout rooms were too frequent and rather uncomfortable.
I liked the breakout rooms and then share oht

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you are in a STEM field some of the issues we talked about are particularly relevant.
Yes, it was a relaxed and accessible forum for discussing issues in data science ethics.
Yes, if you want a chill course that teaches you to think about the societal problems related to fairness in AI

Data Science Ethics was without a doubt the easiest class I took in four years at Yale. If that alone is a good enough reason to take a class, go for it. Beyond that, though, I found it quite disappointing. I came in extremely interested in the societal impacts of big data and artificial intelligence, yet looking back I can't recall what I actually learned. We covered a number of fascinating topics like automation, surveillance, and definitions of fairness; however, these complicated issues were always stripped of nuance and presented in a one-sided manner, with the good side being the leftist perspective. I'm by no means conservative, or even centrist, but as someone who's not a fan of Critical Race Theory and Intersectional Feminism this class did give me pause. A few things students or the professor mentioned: We should defund, not reform, the police; religion isn't a determinant of privilege; black people should only trust ~algorithms~ made by black people. All in all, while Professor Celis and Vijay are wonderful people, this course was neither as engaging nor as insightful as I had hoped.

YES! This is a great senior "gut" -- it's a class that flexibly expands and contracts to take up as much time as you'd like it to, and even if you put in minimal effort (as I did this semester), you'll still wind up learning quite a bit.
YES everyone should take it
Absolutely! Its a very interesting and easy going class.
Yes, the material is interesting and Professor Celis is a joy.

Yes, Id definitely recommend this class to another student. Especially, students majoring in S&DS and CS should take this class because one should be aware of the direct and indirect implications one's work can have.
